title: Rewrite database (SQL) connection storage
author: kmscode
body_snippet:
Feature was experimental to being with. Lots of bugs/feature requests in JIRA (see list below).

In addition, would be beneficial to have support for MySQL/MariaDB, and/or SQLite. More general DB handling code could be implemented in order to support multiple DB types.

JIRA tickets:
https://mremoteng.atlassian.net/browse/MR-923
https://mremoteng.atlassian.net/browse/MR-899
https://mremoteng.atlassian.net/browse/MR-845
https://mremoteng.atlassian.net/browse/MR-793
https://mremoteng.atlassian.net...

iterations.description: Major architectural rewrite of SQL storage layer is out of scope for our fork — this is a large-scale feature requiring upstream consensus and dedicated contributors

comments.snippet: Google Drive support would make sense too. You login with your company's credentials. comments.author: merarischroeder
comments.snippet:
@Kvarkas 

That sounds really good.

I don't think a jump server would be required even today with the System.Net.Socket namespace. See https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/420

I mention in there about a planned OpenSource connection library. This will be part of an OpenSource access toolset that will be able to manage the connections as you describe, but also beyond. EG. If you need to connect over VPN to a device, then from that device to another device for example.

comments.author: Kvarkas
comments.snippet: @merarischroeder I am working with a banks and they like to have jump servers so they control who have access to it (even if its require costly ACL licences) and firewalls are very strict so they only allow remote port to be opened and only for servers they want to be accessed so its depends, but yes that should not stop us from using modern approaches :)

notes:
AI triage: Major architectural rewrite of SQL storage layer is out of scope for our fork — this is a large-scale feature requiring upstream consensus and dedicated contributors
Approach: This is a massive rewrite request for the entire database connection storage subsystem, not a targeted fix. It requires upstream architectural decisions and sustained contributor effort beyond what our fork handles.
